items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-288-3136. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: In the Fall of 2009, both colleges under the leadership of their respective Presidents and Vice Presidents of Academic Affairs, embarked on a comprehensive plan of action to update and develop the 2010-2025 Educational Facilities Master Plans.  The process included the review and participation of faculty, staff, administrators and community members who provided valuable insight and suggestions throughout the development of the plans. The plans were developed in consultation with the Educational Facilities Planning firm of MAAS Companies.  These Educational Facility Master plans will form the foundation upon which the long range facility master plans will be developed to meet the instructional needs of both colleges.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2010-2025 Educational Facility Master Plans that have been developed for San Jose City and Evergreen Valley Colleges.

items.item_details:
Government Code Section 7908(c) requires that each community college district report its appropriation limit to the Chancellor of the Community Colleges at least annually.
	 
The appropriation limit must be approved by our District's Board of Trustees in accordance with Government Code Section 7910.
	 
After the Board of Trustees' approves the appropriation limit, it will be reported on the Annual Financial and Budget Report to the State Chancellor of Community Colleges, which is due on October 10, 2010.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept the 2010-11 Appropriation Limit (GANN)

items.item_details:
In the Fall of 2009, the District, in conjunction with both colleges, began the process of reviewing and updating their 2010-2025 Educational Facilities Master Plans.  These plans form the foundation upon which the 2010-2025 Facility Master Plans will be developed.  The Educational Master Plan has identified program areas for growth that will require new facilities as well as renovations that will be based on program updates and revisions.  This initial facilities information will generate the colleges' long term facility needs and other factors required to support the recommendations of the educational goals and objectives.  In early fall, the Facilities Master Plan will be finalized utilizing the shared governance process at the campuses and the district.  In addition, there is substantial opportunity to implement sustainability and energy efficiency measures that will save the district general fund millions of dollars. This savings could alternatively support student success and preserve critical faculty and staff positions.
	 
On October 27, 2009,  the Board of Trustees participated in a Facilities Study Session that focused on Sustainability, Update on Measure G, Facility Master Planning and Capital Construction Project Approval Processes.  
	 
In the Spring of 2010, the firm of Tramutola LLC conducted a Revenue Measure Feasibility Survey to assess potential voter support for a bond measure to modernize educational facilities and a parcel tax measure to protect community colleges from state budget cuts and maintain critical educational programs. The driving force of the Feasibility Study was a public opinion survey conducted among 500 likely voters in March 2010.  Results of the Feasibility Study suggest that if packaged appropriately and assuming a quality independently funded campaign to educate and mobilize support among voters, a local General Obligation Bond measure has a good chance of passage on the November 2010 ballot. Given this positive evidence that SJECCD can be successful if it places a prudent, responsible GO Bond proposal before the voters in November, District consultants will present highlights of their study, an overview of the election process and timeline, and provide recommendations for moving forward. 
	 
The Educational Facilities Master Plans and the Revenue Measure Feasibility Study will form the basis upon which the district will decide on the pursuit of a General Obligation Bond for Capital Construction and support of educational facilities in an amount that is perishable under the legal provisions set by law.

items.item_details: The development of a North District educational center was part of the original Measure G bond allocation in the Milpitas area.  After several years of negotiations with the Milpitas Unified School District, an agreement has been reached with the development of an Educational Center on the campus of Milpitas High School.  Our Educational Facilities consultant has developed an instructional plan for this center that will also require approval from State Chancellor's Office as an "off site" center.  Follow up action will include the solicitation of a design-build team to implement the project.  A budget of $10 million has been set aside for this project.
Acting Chancellor Treadway will provide a legislative and budget update.
